column2: several state judges denied appointed appellate counsel to indigents pleading guilty
column3: and the Michigan Legislature subsequently codified this practice.  The two attorney respondents joined three indigent criminal defendants in filing suit in Federal District Court
column4: alleging that the practice denies indigents their federal due process and equal protection rights.  The District Court held the practice and statute unconstitutional
column5: but a Sixth Circuit panel reversed
column6: holding that Younger v. Harris
column9: but that the attorneys had third-party standing to assert the indigents rights; and that the statute was constitutional.  On rehearing

column1: Held:The attorneys lack third-party standing to assert the rights of Michigan indigent defendants denied appellate counsel.  The Court assumes that the attorneys have satisfied Article IIIs standing requirement and thus addresses only whether they have standing to raise the rights of others.  In deciding whether to grant third-party standing
column2: this Court asks whether the party asserting the right has a close relationship with the person who possesses the right
column3: and whether there is a hindrance to the possessors ability to protect his own interests.  Powers v. Ohio
column5: 411.  The attorneys here claim standing based on a future attorney-client relationship with as yet unascertained Michigan criminal defendants who will request
column6: but be denied
column7: appellate counsel under the statute.  In two cases in which this Court found an attorney-client relationship sufficient to confer third-party standingCaplin & Drysdale
column10: and Department of Labor v. Triplett
column11: 494 U. S. 715the attorneys invoked known clients rights
column12: not those of the hypothetical clients asserted here.  And Department of Labor v. Triplettin which an attorney disciplined by his state bar for accepting a fee prohibited by the Black Lung Benefits Act of 1972 was held to have third-party standing to invoke claimants due process rights to challenge the fee restriction that resulted in his punishmentfalls within the class of cases allowing standing to litigate the rights of third parties when enforc[ing] the challenged restriction against the litigant would result indirectly in the violation of third parties rights
column13: Warth v. Seldin
column15: 510.  The attorneys here do not have a close relationship with their alleged clients; indeed
column16: they have no relationship at all.   Nor have they demonstrated any hindrance to the indigents advancing their own constitutional rights against the Michigan scheme.  An indigent may seek leave to challenge the denial of appellate counsel in state court and then may seek a writ of certiorari in this Court; and both state and federal collateral review exist beyond that.  The attorneys hypothesis that
column18: such avenues are effectively foreclosed was disproved in the Michigan courts and this Court
column19: where pro se indigents have pursued them.  On a more fundamental level
column20: if an attorney is all that the indigents need to perfect their challenge in state court and beyond
column21: one wonders why these attorneys did not attend state court and assist them.  The fair inference is that they did not want the state process to take its course
column22: but wanted a federal court to short-circuit the States adjudication of the constitutional question.  Here
column23: the indigents were appropriately dismissed under Younger because they had ample opportunities to raise their constitutional challenge in their ongoing state proceedings.  An unwillingness to allow the Younger principle to be thus circumvented is an additional reason to deny the attorneys third-party standing.  Pp.28.

column3: terminated a police officer
column5: for selling videotapes he made and for related activity.  The tapes showed the respondent engaging in sexually explicit acts.  Respondent brought suit alleging
column6: among other things

column1: The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted

column1: Roes supervisor

column9: Roe produced a custom video.  It showed Roe
column10: again in police uniform
column11: issuing a traffic citation but revoking it after undoing the uniform and masturbating.

column1: The investigation revealed that Roes conduct violated specific SDPD policies
column2: including conduct unbecoming of an officer
column3: outside employment
column5: Roe admitted to selling the videos and police paraphernalia.  The SDPD ordered Roe to cease displaying
column6: manufacturing

column9: U. S. Mail

column11: or any other medium available to the public.  356 F.3d

column14: which described the first two videos he had produced and listed their prices as well as the prices for custom videos.  After discovering Roes failure to follow its orders

column3: alleging that the employment termination violated his First Amendment right to free speech.  In granting summary judgment to the City

column2: the Court of Appeals held Roes conduct fell within the protected category of citizen commentary on matters of public concern.  Central to the Court of Appeals conclusion was that Roes expression was not an internal workplace grievance

column1: II
A government employee does not relinquish all First Amendment rights otherwise enjoyed by citizens just by reason of his or her employment.  See
column3: Keyishian v. Board of Regents of Univ. of State of N. Y.
column5: 605606 (1967).  On the other hand
column6: a governmental employer may impose certain restraints on the speech of its employees
column7: restraints that would be unconstitutional if applied to the general public.  The Court has recognized the right of employees to speak on matters of public concern
column8: typically matters concerning government policies that are of interest to the public at large
column9: a subject on which public employees are uniquely qualified to comment.  See Connick
column10: supra; Pickering v. Board of Ed. of Township High School Dist. 205
column12: 391 U. S. 563 (1968). Outside of this category
column13: the Court has held that when government employees speak or write on their own time on topics unrelated to their employment
column14: the speech can have First Amendment protection
column15: absent some governmental justification far stronger than mere speculation in regulating it.  United States v. Treasury Employees
column18: 475 (1995) (NTEU).  We have little difficulty in concluding that the City was not barred from terminating Roe under either line of cases.

column1: A
In concluding that Roes activities qualified as a matter of public concern
column2: the Court of Appeals relied heavily on the Courts decision in NTEU.  356 F.3d
column3: at 1117.  In NTEU it was established that the speech was unrelated to the employment and had no effect on the mission and purpose of the employer.  The question was whether the Federal Government could impose certain monetary limitations on outside earnings from speaking or writing on a class of federal employees.  The Court held that
column4: within the particular classification of employment
column5: the Government had shown no justification for the outside salary limitations.  The First Amendment right of the employees sufficed to invalidate the restrictions on the outside earnings for such activities.  The Court noted that throughout history public employees who undertook to write or to speak in their spare time had made substantial contributions to literature and art
column6: NTEU
column7: supra
column9: and observed that none of the speech at issue even arguably [had] any adverse impact on the employer.  Ibid.

column3: Roe took deliberate steps to link his videos and other wares to his police work

column5: the law enforcement reference in the Web site
column6: the listing of the speaker as in the field of law enforcement
column7: and the debased parody of an officer performing indecent acts while in the course of official duties brought the mission of the employer and the professionalism of its officers into serious disrepute.  356 F.3d

It is quite a different question whether the speech was detrimental to the SDPD.  On that score the Citys consistent position has been that the speech is contrary to its regulations and harmful to the proper functioning of the police force. The present case falls outside the protection afforded in NTEU.  The authorities that instead control

column7: supra

column1: B
To reconcile the employees right to engage in speech and the government employers right to protect its own legitimate interests in performing its mission
column2: the Pickering Court adopted a balancing test.  It requires a court evaluating restraints on a public employees speech to balance the interests of the [employee]
column3: as a citizen
column4: in commenting upon matters of public concern and the interest of the State
column5: as an employer
column6: in promoting the efficiency of the public services it performs through its employees.  391 U. S.
column7: at 568; see also Connick

column1: Underlying the decision in Pickering is the recognition that public employees are often the members of the community who are likely to have informed opinions as to the operations of their public employers
column2: operations which are of substantial concern to the public.  Were they not able to speak on these matters
column3: the community would be deprived of informed opinions on important public issues.  See 391 U. S.
column4: at 572.  The interest at stake is as much the publics interest in receiving informed opinion as it is the employees own right to disseminate it.

column1: Pickering did not hold that any and all statements by a public employee are entitled to balancing.  To require Pickering balancing in every case where speech by a public employee is at issue

column3: could compromise the proper functioning of government offices.  See Connick
column5: at 143. This concern prompted the Court in Connick to explain a threshold inquiry (implicit in Pickering itself) that in order to merit Pickering balancing
column6: a public employees speech must touch on a matter of public concern.  461 U. S.
column7: at 143 (internal quotation marks omitted).

column5: as revealed by the whole record in assessing whether an employees speech addresses a matter of public concern.  Id.

column7: it notes that the standard for determining whether expression is of public concern is the same standard used to determine whether a common-law action for invasion of privacy is present.  Id.
column9: n. 5.  That standard is established by our decisions in Cox Broadcasting Corp. v. Cohn
column12: Inc. v. Hill
column14: 387388 (1967).  These cases make clear that public concern is something that is a subject of legitimate news interest; that is
column15: a subject of general interest and of value and concern to the public at the time of publication.  The Court has also recognized that certain private remarks
column16: such as negative comments about the President of the United States

column1: Applying these principles to the instant case

column1: Connick is controlling precedent
column2: but to show why this is not a close case it is instructive to note that even under the view expressed by the dissent in Connick from four Members of the Court
column3: the speech here would not come within the definition of a matter of public concern.  The dissent in Connick would have held that the entirety of the questionnaire circulated by the employee discussed subjects that could reasonably be expected to be of interest to persons seeking to develop informed opinions about the manner in which . . . an elected official charged with managing a vital governmental agency
column5: at 163 (opinion of Brennan
column6: J.).  No similar purpose could be attributed to the employees speech in the present case.  Roes activities did nothing to inform the public about any aspect of the SDPDs functioning or operation.  Nor were Roes activities anything like the private remarks at issue in Rankin
column7: where one co-worker commented to another co-worker on an item of political news.  Roes expression was widely broadcast
column8: linked to his official status as a police officer
column9: and designed to exploit his employers image.

column1: The speech in question was detrimental to the mission and functions of the employer.  There is no basis for finding that it was of concern to the community as the Courts cases have understood that term in the context of restrictions by governmental entities on the speech of their employees.
The judgment of the Court of Appeals is
Reversed.

column2: petitioner was convicted of brutally murdering one of his former co-workers at a Taco Bell in Dallas County.  The victim and one of her co-workers were closing down the restaurant when petitioner and several friends asked to be let in to use the telephone.  The two employees recognized petitioner and let him in.  Petitioner then told his former co-workers to leave because he wanted to rob the restaurant.  When they did not leave

column5: his other former co-worker before exiting with his friends.  The jury found petitioner guilty of capital murder beyond a reasonable doubt.

column9: 328 (1989) (Penry I).  Shortly after petitioners trial

The state court and the Fifth Circuit both held that the lack of an adequate mitigation instruction was irrelevant. column15: the shore is now an artificial place to draw a line.  Maritime commerce has evolved along with the nature of transportation and is often inseparable from some land-based obligations.  The international transportation industry has moved into a new era
column16: in which cargo owners can contract for transportation across oceans and to inland destinations in a single transaction.  The popularity of an efficient choice

column18: should not render bills for ocean carriage nonmaritime contracts.  Lower court cases that appear to have depended solely on geography in fashioning a rule for identifying maritime contracts are inconsistent with the conceptual approach required by this Courts precedent.  Pp.  610.

column2: 359 U. S. 297.  Deriving a principle of narrow construction from Herd
column3: the Court of Appeals concluded that the language of the ICC bills Himalaya Clause is too vague to clearly include Norfolk.  Moreover
column4: it interpreted Herd to require privity between the carrier and the party seeking shelter under a Himalaya Clause.  Nothing in Herd requires such linguistic specificity or privity rules. The Eleventh Circuits ruling is not true to the contract language or the parties intent.  The plain language of the Himalaya Clause indicates an intent to extend the liability limitation broadly and corresponds to the fact that various modes of transportation would be involved in performing the contract.  Since Huntsville is some 366 miles inland from the discharge port
column5: the parties must have anticipated using a land carriers services for the contracts performance.  Because it is clear that a railroad was an intended beneficiary of the ICC bills broadly written clause

column2: the Court draws a rule from the common carriage decision of Great Northern R. Co. v. OConnor
column3: 232 U. S. 508: When an intermediary contracts with a carrier to transport goods
column4: the cargo owners recovery against the carrier is limited by the liability limitation to which the intermediary and carrier agreed.  The intermediary is not the cargo owners agent in every sense
column5: but it can negotiate reliable and enforceable liability limitations with carriers it engages. It is of no moment that the traditional indicia of agency did not exist between Kirby and ICC
column6: for the Great Northern principle only requires treating ICC as Kirbys agent for a single
column7: limited purpose: when ICC contracts with subsequent carriers for liability limitations.  Nor will a decision binding Kirby to the Hamburg Sd bills liability limitation be disastrous for the international shipping industry.  First
column8: a limited agency rule tracks industry practices.  Second
column9: if liability limitations negotiated with cargo owners were reliable while those negotiated with intermediaries were not
column10: carriers would likely want to charge the latter higher rates
column11: resulting in discrimination in common carriage.  Finally
column12: this decision produces an equitable result
column13: since Kirby retains the right to sue ICC
column15: for any loss exceeding the liability limitation to which they agreed.  See id.

column1: (a)Respondents threshold argument that the transactions fall outside the FTAIA because its general exclusionary rule applies only to conduct involving exports is rejected.  The House Judiciary Committee changed the bills original language from export trade or export commerce
column3: to trade or commerce (other than import trade or import commerce) deliberately to include commerce that did not involve American exports but was wholly foreign.  Pp.56.

column1: (b)The FTAIA exception does not apply here for two reasons.  First
column2: this Court ordinarily construes ambiguous statutes to avoid unreasonable interference with other nations sovereign authority.  This rule of construction reflects customary international law principles and cautions courts to assume that legislators take account of other nations legitimate sovereign interests when writing American laws.  It thereby helps the potentially conflicting laws of different nations work together in harmony.  While applying Americas antitrust laws to foreign conduct can interfere with a foreign nations ability to regulate its own commercial affairs
column3: courts have long held such application nonetheless reasonable
column4: and hence consistent with prescriptive comity principles
column5: insofar as the laws reflect a legislative effort to redress domestic antitrust injury caused by foreign anticompetitive conduct.  However
column6: it is not reasonable to apply American laws to foreign conduct insofar as that conduct causes independent foreign harm that alone gives rise to a plaintiffs claim.  The risk of interference is the same
column7: but the justification for the interference seems insubstantial.  While some of the anticompetitive conduct alleged here took place in America
column8: the higher foreign prices are not the consequence of any domestic anticompetitive conduct sought to be forbidden by Congress
column9: which rather wanted to release domestic (and foreign) anticompetitive conduct from Sherman Act constraint when that conduct causes foreign harm.  Contrary to respondents claim
column10: the comity concerns remain real as other nations have not in all areas adopted antitrust laws similar to this countrys and
column12: disagree dramatically about appropriate remedies.  Respondents alternative argument that case-by-case comity analysis is preferable to an across the board exclusion of foreign injury cases is too complex to prove workable.  Second
column13: the FTAIAs language and history suggest that Congress designed the Act to clarify
column15: but not to expand
column16: the Sherman Acts scope as applied to foreign commerce.  There is no significant indication that at the time Congress wrote the FTAIA courts would have thought the Sherman Act applicable in these circumstances
column17: nor do the six cases on which respondents rely warrant a different conclusion.  Pp.616.

column1: (c)Respondents additional linguistic arguments might show a natural reading of the statute
column2: but the comity and history considerations previously discussed make clear that respondents reading is not consistent with the FTAIAs basic intent.  Their deterrence-based policy argument is also unavailing in light of the contrary arguments by the antitrust enforcement agencies.  Pp.1618.

column1: (d)On remand
column2: the Court of Appeals may consider whether respondents properly preserved their alternative argument that the foreign injury here was not in fact independent of the domestic effects; and
column3: if so
column4: it may consider and decide the related claim.  Pp.1819.

column1: 02-473||"UNITED STATES v. BANKS
certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the ninth circuit
No. 02473. Argued October 15
When federal and local law enforcement officers went to respondent Bankss apartment to execute a warrant to search for cocaine
column2: they called out police search warrant and rapped on the front door hard enough to be heard by officers at the back door
column3: waited for 15 to 20 seconds with no response
column4: and then broke open the door.  Banks was in the shower and testified that he heard nothing until the crash of the door.  The District Court denied his motion to suppress the drugs and weapons found during the search
column5: rejecting his argument that the officers waited an unreasonably short time before forcing entry in violation of both the Fourth Amendment and 18 U. S.C. 3109.  Banks pleaded guilty
column6: but reserved his right to challenge the search on appeal.  In reversing and ordering the evidence suppressed
column7: the Ninth Circuit found
column8: using a four-part scheme for vetting knock-and-announce entries
column9: that the instant entry had no exigent circumstances
column10: making forced entry by destruction of property permissible only if there was an explicit refusal of admittance or a time lapse greater than the one here.

column1: Held:
1.The officers 15-to-20-second wait before forcible entry satisfied the Fourth Amendment.  Pp.411.

(a)The standards bearing on whether officers can legitimately enter after knocking are the same as those for requiring or dispensing with knock and announce altogether.  This Court has fleshed out the notion of reasonable execution on a case-by-case basis
column2: but has pointed out factual considerations of unusual
column3: albeit not dispositive
column4: significance.  The obligation to knock and announce before entering gives way when officers have reasonable grounds to expect futility or to suspect that an exigency
column5: such as evidence destruction
column6: will arise instantly upon knocking.  Richards v. Wisconsin
column8: 394.  Since most people keep their doors locked
column9: a no-knock entry will normally do some damage
column10: a fact too common to require a heightened justification when a reasonable suspicion of exigency already justifies an unwarned entry.  United States v. Ramirez

column1: (b)This case turns on the exigency revealed by the circumstances known to the officers after they knocked and announced
column2: which the Government contends was the risk of losing easily disposable evidence.  After 15 to 20 seconds without a response
column3: officers could fairly have suspected that Banks would flush away the cocaine if they remained reticent.  Each of Bankss counterargumentsthat he was in the shower and did not hear the officers
column4: and that it might have taken him longer than 20 seconds to reach the doorrests on a mistake about the relevant enquiry.  As to the first argument
column5: the facts known to the police are what count in judging a reasonable waiting time
column6: and there is no indication that they knew that Banks was in the shower and thus unaware of an impending search.  As to the second
column7: the crucial fact is not the time it would take Banks to reach the door but the time it would take him to destroy the cocaine.  It is not unreasonable to think that someone could get in a position to destroy the drugs within 15 to 20 seconds.  Once the exigency had matured
column8: the officers were not bound to learn anything more or wait any longer before entering
column9: even though the entry entailed some harm to the building.  Pp.69.

column1: (c)This Courts emphasis on totality analysis leads it to reject the Governments position that the need to damage property should not be part of the analysis of whether the entry itself was reasonable and to disapprove of the Ninth Circuits four-part vetting scheme.  Pp.1011.
2.The entry here also satisfied 18 U. S.C. 3109
column2: which permits entry by force if
column3: after notice of his authority and purpose
column4: [an officer] is refused admittance.  Because 3109 implicates the exceptions to the common law knock-and-announce requirement that inform the Fourth Amendment itself
column5: 3109 is also subject to an exigent circumstances exception
column6: which qualifies the requirement of refusal after notice
column7: just as it qualifies the obligation to announce in the first place.  Pp.1112.

This was the common usage of arising under in contemporary state borrowing statutes used to determine which States limitations statute applied in cases with transjurisdictional facts. Five days before the 1-year statute of limitations under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA) would have run
column2: respondent filed two pro se mixed federal habeas petitionsthose containing both unexhausted and exhausted claimsand motions to stay the petitions while he returned to state court to exhaust the unexhausted claims.  The Magistrate Judge gave him three options:(1) The petitions could be dismissed without prejudice and respondent could refile after exhausting the unexhausted claims; (2) the unexhausted claims could be dismissed and he could proceed with only the exhausted claims; or (3) he could contest the Magistrate Judges finding that some claims were unexhausted.  He chose the first option with respect to one petition and failed to respond with respect to the other.  The Federal District Court dismissed his petitions without prejudice.  He then filed habeas petitions in the California Supreme Court
column3: which were both denied.  The federal court dismissed his subsequently refiled pro se habeas petitions with prejudice as untimely under AEDPA
column5: and denied him a certificate of appealability (COA).  The Ninth Circuit granted a COA
column6: concluding that his initial petitions were timely under 2254(d) and that his later petitions related back to the initial ones.  The Ninth Circuit determined that although the District Court correctly concluded that it did not have discretion to stay respondents mixed petitions
column7: it could have acted on his stay motions had he chosen the Magistrate Judges second option and then renewed the prematurely filed stay motions.  It also held that the District Court had to give respondent two specific warnings: first
column8: that it could not consider his motions to stay the mixed petitions unless he chose to amend them and dismiss the then-unexhausted claims; and second
column9: if applicable
column10: that his federal claims would be time barred
column12: upon his return to federal court if he opted to dismiss the petitions without prejudice and return to state court to exhaust all his claims.

column1: Held:The District Court was not required to provide the warnings directed by the Ninth Circuit.  Pp.49.
(a)Federal district courts must dismiss mixed habeas petitions.  Rose v. Lundy
column3: 522.  The combined effect of Rose and AEDPAs limitations period is that if a petitioner comes to federal court with a mixed petition toward the end of the limitations period
column4: a dismissal of his mixed petition could result in the loss of all his claimsincluding those already exhaustedbecause the limitations period could expire during the time he returns to state court to exhaust his unexhausted claims.  To address this
column5: the Ninth Circuit allows a district court to employ a stay-and-abeyance procedure
column6: which involves (1) dismissal of any unexhausted claims from the original mixed habeas petition; (2) a stay of the remaining claims
column7: pending exhaustion of the dismissed unexhausted claims in state court; and (3) amendment of the original petition to add the newly exhausted claims that then relate back to the original petition.  Here
column8: the Ninth Circuit held that if a pro se prisoner files a mixed petition
column9: the district court must give two specific warnings regarding the stay-and-abeyance procedure.  But federal district judges have no obligation to act as counsel or paralegal to pro se litigants.  See
column10: e.g.
column13: 183184.  Explaining the details of federal habeas procedure and calculating statutes of limitations are tasks normally and properly performed by trained counsel.  Requiring district courts to advise pro se litigants in such a manner would undermine district judges role as impartial decisionmakers.  And the warnings run the risk of being misleading.  The first could encourage the use of stay-and-abeyance when it is not in the petitioners best interest.  The second would force upon judges the potentially burdensome task of making a case-specific calculation of whether the AEDPA limitations period has already run or will have run by the time the petitioner returns to federal court.  Because such calculations depend upon information contained in documents that do not necessarily accompany the petition
column14: a district judges calculation could be in error and thereby misinform a pro se petitioner.  Respondents argument that Rose requires that a prisoner be given the choice of returning to state court to exhaust his claims or amending or resubmitting the habeas petition to present only exhausted claims to the district court
column16: at 510
column17: is unavailing.  Rose requires only that a district court dismiss mixed petitions
column20: means that the prisoner must follow one of these two paths if he wants to proceed with his federal petition.  Nothing in Rose requires that both options be equally attractive
column21: or that district judges give specific advisements as to the availability and wisdom of these options.  Respondents reliance on Castro v. United States
column23: is misplaced
column24: because Castro dealt with a district courts sU. S.onte recharacterization of a prisoners pleading and did not address whether a district court is required to explain a pro se litigants options before a voluntary dismissal.  Pp.48.

column1: (a)Under the constructive discharge doctrine
column2: an employees reasonable decision to resign because of unendurable working conditions is assimilated to a formal discharge for remedial purposes.  The inquiry is objective: Did working conditions become so intolerable that a reasonable person in the employees position would have felt compelled to resign?  This doctrine was developed by the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) in the 1930s

column1: |541 u.s. 739|"CENTRAL LABORERS PENSION FUND v. HEINZ
et al.
certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the seventh circuit
No. 02891. Argued April 19
Respondents (collectively
column2: Heinz) are retired participants in a multiemployer pension plan (hereinafter Plan) administered by petitioner.  Heinz retired from the construction industry after accruing enough pension credits to qualify for early retirement payments under a service only pension scheme that pays him the same monthly benefit he would have received had he retired at the usual age.  The Plan prohibits such beneficiaries from certain disqualifying employment after they retire
column3: suspending monthly payments until they stop the forbidden work.  When Heinz retired
column4: the Plan defined disqualifying employment to include a job as a construction worker but not as a supervisor
column5: the job Heinz took.  In 1998
column6: the Plan expanded its definition to include any construction industry job and stopped Heinzs payments when he did not leave his supervisors job.  Heinz sued to recover the suspended benefits
column7: claiming that the suspension violated the anti-cutback rule of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA)
column8: which prohibits any pension plan amendment that would reduce a participants accrued benefit
column9: ERISA 204(g)
column10: 29 U. S.C. 1054(g).  The District Court granted the Plan judgment on the pleadings
column12: holding that imposing new conditions on rights to benefits already accrued violates the anti-cutback rule.

column1: Held:ERISA 204(g) prohibits a plan amendment expanding the categories of postretirement employment that triggers suspension of the payment of early retirement benefits already accrued.  Pp.311.
(a)The anti-cutback provision is crucial to ERISAs central object of protecting employees justified expectations of receiving the benefits that they have been promised
column4: 887.  The provision prohibits plan amendments that have the effect of  eliminating or reducing an early retirement benefit. 29 U. S.C. 1054(g)(2).  The question here is whether the Plans amendment had such an effect.  Although the statutory text is not as helpful as it might be
column5: it is clear as a matter of common sense that a benefit has suffered under the amendment.  Heinz accrued benefits under a plan allowing him to supplement his retirement income
column6: and he reasonably relied on that plans terms in planning his retirement.  The 1998 amendment undercut that reliance
column7: paying benefits only if he accepted a substantial curtailment of his opportunity to do the kind of work he knew.  There is no way that
column9: this change of terms could not be viewed as shrinking the value of Heinzs pension rights and reducing his promised benefits.  Pp.35.

column1: (b)The Plans technical responses are rejected.  To give the anti-cutback rule the constricted reading urged by the Planapplying it only to amendments directly altering the monthly payments nominal dollar amount and not to a suspension when the amount that would be paid is unalteredwould take textual force majeure
column2: and certainly something closer to irresistible than language in 29 U. S.C. 1002(23)(A) to the effect that accrued benefits are ordinarily expressed in the form of an annual benefit commencing at normal retirement age.  And the Plans argument that 204(g)s eliminat[e] or reduc[e] language does not apply to mere suspensions misses the point.  ERISA permits conditions that are elements of the benefit itself but the question here is whether a new condition may be imposed after a benefit has accrued.  The right to receive certain money on a certain date may not be limited by a new condition narrowing that right.  Pp.56.

column1: (c)This Courts conclusion is confirmed by an Internal Revenue Service regulation that adopts the reading of 204(g) approved here.  Pp.69.

column1: certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the eleventh circuit
No. 036821. Argued March 29
Three days before his scheduled execution by lethal injection
column2: petitioner filed a 42 U. S.C. 1983 action against respondent Alabama prison officials
column3: alleging that the use of a cut-down procedure requiring an incision into his arm or leg to access his severely compromised veins constituted cruel and unusual punishment and deliberate indifference to his medical needs in violation of the Eighth Amendment.  Petitioner
column4: who had already filed an unsuccessful federal habeas application
column5: sought a permanent injunction against the cut-downs use
column6: a temporary stay of execution so the District Court could consider his claims merits
column7: and orders requiring respondents to furnish a copy of the protocol on the medical procedures for venous access and directing them to promulgate a venous access protocol that comports with contemporary standards.  Respondents moved to dismiss the complaint for want of jurisdiction on the grounds that the 1983 claim and stay request were the equivalent of a second or successive habeas application subject to 28 U. S.C. 2244(b)s gatekeeping requirements.  Agreeing
column8: the District Court dismissed the complaint because petitioner had not obtained authorization to file such an application.  In affirming
column9: the Eleventh Circuit held that method-of-execution challenges necessarily sound in habeas
column10: and that it would have denied a habeas authorization request.

column1: Held:Section 1983 is an appropriate vehicle for petitioners Eighth Amendment claim seeking a temporary stay and permanent injunctive relief.  Pp.513.

(a)Section 1983 must yield to the federal habeas statute where an inmate seeks injunctive relief challenging the fact of his conviction or the duration of his sentence.  Such claims fall within the core of habeas.  By contrast
column2: constitutional claims challenging confinement conditions fall outside of that core and may be brought under 1983 in the first instance.  The Court need not reach here the difficult question of how method-of-execution claims should be classified generally.  Respondents have conceded that 1983 would be the appropriate vehicle for an inmate who is not facing execution to bring a deliberate indifference challenge to the cut-down procedures constitutionality if used to gain venous access for medical treatment.  There is no reason on the complaints face to treat petitioners claim differently solely because he has been condemned to die.  Respondents claim that because the cut-down is part of the execution procedure
column3: petitioner is actually challenging the fact of his execution.  However
column4: that venous access is a necessary prerequisite to execution does not imply that a particular means of gaining such access is likewise necessary.  Petitioner has argued throughout the proceedings that the cut-down and the wardens refusal to provide reliable information on the cut-down protocol are wholly unnecessary to gaining venous access.  If
column5: after an evidentiary hearing
column6: the District Court finds the cut-down necessary
column7: it will need to address the broader method-of-execution question left open here.  The instant holding is consistent with this Courts approach to civil rights damages actions
column8: which also fall at the margins of habeas.  Pp.59.

column1: (b)If a permanent injunction request does not sound in habeas
column2: it follows that the lesser-included request for a temporary stay (or preliminary injunction) does not either.  Here
column3: a fair reading of the complaint leaves no doubt that petitioner sought to enjoin the cut-down
column4: not his execution by lethal injection.  However
column5: his stay request asked to stay his execution
column6: seemingly without regard to whether the State did or did not resort to the cut-down.  The execution warrant has now expired.  If the State reschedules the execution while this case is pending on remand and petitioner seeks another similarly broad stay
column7: the District Court will need to address the question whether a request to enjoin the execution
column8: rather than merely to enjoin an allegedly unnecessary precursor medical procedure
column9: properly sounds in habeas.  Pp.911.

column1: (c)Respondents are incorrect that a reversal here would open the floodgates to all manner of method-of-execution challenges and last-minute stay requests.  Because this Court does not here resolve the question of how to treat method-of-execution claims generally
column2: the instant holding is extremely limited.  Moreover
column3: merely stating a cognizable 1983 claim does not warrant a stay as a matter of right.  A court may consider a stay applications last-minute nature in deciding whether to grant such equitable relief.  And the ability to bring a 1983 claim does not free inmates from the substantive or procedural limitations of the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1995.  Pp.1113.

column2: alleging that Tennessee and a number of its counties had denied them physical access to that States courts in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA)

column5: be excluded from participation or denied the benefits of the services

column9: 531 U. S. 356.  This Court later ruled in Garrett that the Eleventh Amendment bars private money damages actions for state violations of ADA Title I
column10: which prohibits employment discrimination against the disabled.  The en banc Sixth Circuit then issued its Popovich decision
column11: in which it interpreted Garrett to bar private ADA suits against States based on equal protection principles
column12: but not those relying on due process
column13: and therefore permitted a Title II damages action to proceed despite the States immunity claim.  Thereafter

column16: the panel filed an amended opinion

column20: that physical barriers in courthouses and courtrooms have had the effect of denying disabled people the opportunity for such access.

column1: Held:As it applies to the class of cases implicating the fundamental right of access to the courts
column2: Title II constitutes a valid exercise of Congress authority under 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment to enforce that Amendments substantive guarantees.  Pp.423.

column1: (a)Determining whether Congress has constitutionally abrogated a States Eleventh Amendment immunity requires resolution of two predicate questions: (1) whether Congress unequivocally expressed its intent to abrogate; and (2)
column3: whether it acted pursuant to a valid grant of constitutional authority.  Kimel v. Florida Bd. of Regents
column5: 73.  The first question is easily answered here
column6: since the ADA specifically provides for abrogation.  See 12202.  With regard to the second question
column7: Congress can abrogate state sovereign immunity pursuant to a valid exercise of its power under 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment.  E.g.
column10: 456.  That power is not
column12: unlimited.  While Congress must have a wide berth in devising appropriate remedial and preventative measures for unconstitutional actions
column13: those measures may not work a substantive change in the governing law.  City of Boerne v. Flores
column15: 519.  In Boerne
column16: the Court set forth the test for distinguishing between permissible remedial legislation and unconstitutional substantive redefinition: Section 5 legislation is valid if it exhibits a congruence and proportionality between an injury and the means adopted to prevent or remedy it.  Id.
column17: at 520.  Applying the Boerne test in Garrett
column18: the Court concluded that ADA Title I was not a valid exercise of Congress 5 power because the historical record and the statutes broad sweep suggested that Title Is true aim was not so much enforcement
column19: but an attempt to rewrite this Courts Fourteenth Amendment jurisprudence.  531 U. S.
column20: at 372374.  In view of significant differences between Titles I and II
column21: however
column22: Garrett left open the question whether Title II is a valid exercise of Congress 5 power
column23: id.
column24: at 360

column1: (b)Title II is a valid exercise of Congress 5 enforcement power.  Pp.1123.
(1)The Boerne inquirys first step requires identification of the constitutional rights Congress sought to enforce when it enacted Title II.  Garrett
column3: at 365.  Like Title I
column4: Title II seeks to enforce the Fourteenth Amendments prohibition on irrational disability discrimination
column5: Garrett
column7: at 366.  But it also seeks to enforce a variety of other basic constitutional guarantees
column9: like the right of access to the courts here at issue

column12: Dunn v. Blumstein
column14: 336337.  Whether Title II validly enforces such constitutional rights is a question that must be judged with reference to the historical experience which it reflects.  E.g.

column1: |540 u.s. 749|"SHAKUR MUHAMMAD
PETITIONER v. MARK CLOSE
on writ of certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the sixth circuit
[February 25
Per Curiam.
I
Federal law opens two main avenues to relief on complaints related to imprisonment: a petition for habeas corpus
column3: and a complaint under the Civil Rights Act of 1871
column5: as amended
column6: 42 U. S.C. 1983.  Challenges to the validity of any confinement or to particulars affecting its duration are the province of habeas corpus
column7: Preiser v. Rodriguez
column9: 500 (1973); requests for relief turning on circumstances of confinement may be presented in a 1983 action.  Some cases are hybrids
column10: with a prisoner seeking relief unavailable in habeas
column12: but on allegations that not only support a claim for recompense
column13: but imply the invalidity either of an underlying conviction or of a particular ground for denying release short of serving the maximum term of confinement.  In Heck v. Humphrey
column15: we held that where success in a prisoners 1983 damages action would implicitly question the validity of conviction or duration of sentence
column16: the litigant must first achieve favorable termination of his available state
column18: opportunities to challenge the underlying conviction or sentence.  Accordingly
column21: we applied Heck in the circumstances of a 1983 action claiming damages and equitable relief for a procedural defect in a prisons administrative process
column22: where the administrative action taken against the plaintiff could affect credits toward release based on good-time served.  In each instance
column23: conditioning the right to bring a 1983 action on a favorable result in state litigation or federal habeas served the practical objective of preserving limitations on the availability of habeas remedies.  Federal petitions for habeas corpus may be granted only after other avenues of relief have been exhausted.  28 U. S.C. 2254(b)(1)(A).  See Rose v. Lundy
column24: 455 U. S. 509 (1982). Prisoners suing under 1983
column26: generally face a substantially lower gate
column27: even with the requirement of the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1995 that administrative opportunities be exhausted first.  42 U. S.C. 1997e(a).

column1: Hecks requirement to resort to state litigation and federal habeas before 1983 is not
column3: implicated by a prisoners challenge that threatens no consequence for his conviction or the duration of his sentence.[Footnote 1]  There is no need to preserve the habeas exhaustion rule and no impediment under Heck in such a case
column4: of which this is an example.[Footnote 2]

column1: II
A
This suit grew out of a confrontation between petitioner
column3: an inmate
column4: and the respondent Michigan prison official
column5: Close.  App. 70.  According to his amended complaint
column6: Muhammad was eating breakfast when he saw Close staring at him through the hallway window.  Id.
column7: at 71.  Eventually Muhammad stared back
column8: provoking Close to assume a fighting stance and com[e] into the dining area at a fast pace with his face contorted.  Ibid.  Muhammad stood up and faced him
column9: and when the two were within a foot of one another
column10: Close asked
column12: all the while staring angerly [sic].  In the aftermath of the confrontation
column13: Muhammad was handcuffed
column15: and charged with violating the prison rule prohibiting Threatening Behavior.[Footnote 3]  Under the rules
column16: special detention was required prior to a hearing on the charge
column17: which occurred six days later.  Muhammad was acquitted of threatening behavior
column18: but found guilty of the lesser infraction of insolence
column19: for which prehearing detention would not have been mandatory.[Footnote 4]  Ibid.  Muhammad was required to serve an additional 7 days of detention and deprived of privileges for 30 days as penalties for insolence.  Ibid.

column1: Muhammad then brought this 1983 action
column2: alleging that Close had charged him with threatening behavior (and subjected him to mandatory prehearing lockup) in retaliation for prior lawsuits and grievance proceedings against Close.  Id.
column3: at 72.  He amended his original complaint after obtaining counsel
column4: and neither in his amended complaint nor at any subsequent juncture did Muhammad challenge his conviction for insolence
column5: or the subsequent disciplinary action.  See Brief for Petitioner 42.  The amended complaint sought no expungement of the misconduct finding
column6: and in fact Muhammad conceded that the insolence determination was justified.  The only relief sought was $10
column7: 000 in compensatory and punitive damages for the physical
column9: and emotional injuries sustained during the six days of prehearing detention mandated by the charge of threatening behavior attributable to Closes retaliatory motive.  App. 72.

column1: Following discovery
column2: the Magistrate Judge recommended summary judgment for Close on the ground that Muhammad had failed to come forward with sufficient evidence of retaliation to raise a genuine issue of material fact as to that element.  Id.
column3: at 63.  The District Court adopted the recommendation.  Id.

column1: B
Muhammad then appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
column3: by an opinion designated not for publication
column4: affirmed the summary judgment for Close
column5: though not on the basis recommended by the Magistrate Judge and adopted by the District Court.  47 Fed. Appx. 738 (2002).  Instead of considering the conclusion that Muhammad had produced inadequate evidence of retaliation
column6: a ground that would have been dispositive if sustained
column7: the Court of Appeals held the action barred by Heck because Muhammad had sought
column9: the expungement of the misconduct charge from the prison record.  Relying upon Circuit precedent
column10: see Huey v. Stine
column12: the Court of Appeals held that an action under 1983 to expunge his misconduct charge and for other relief occasioned by the misconduct proceedings could be brought only after satisfying Hecks favorable termination requirement.  The Circuit thus maintained a split on the applicability of Heck to prison disciplinary proceedings in the absence of any implication going to the fact or duration of underlying sentence
column13: four Circuits having taken the contrary view.  See Leamer v. Fauver
column15: 542544 (CA3 2002); DeWalt v. Carter
column21: 167169 (CADC 1997).  We granted certiorari to resolve the conflict
column23: and now reverse.

column1: III

The decision of the Court of Appeals was flawed as a matter of fact and as a matter of law.  Its factual error was the assumption that Muhammad sought to expunge the misconduct charge from his prison record.  The court simply overlooked the amended complaint that sought no such relief.

The factual error was compounded by following the mistaken view expressed in Circuit precedent that Heck applies categorically to all suits challenging prison disciplinary proceedings.  But these administrative determinations do not as such raise any implication about the validity of the underlying conviction
column2: and although they may affect the duration of time to be served (by bearing on the award or revocation of good-time credits) that is not necessarily so.  The effect of disciplinary proceedings on good-time credits is a matter of state law or regulation
column3: and in this case
column4: the Magistrate expressly found or assumed that no good-time credits were eliminated by the prehearing action Muhammad called in question.  His 1983 suit challenging this action could not therefore be construed as seeking a judgment at odds with his conviction or with the States calculation of time to be served in accordance with the underlying sentence.  That is
column5: he raised no claim on which habeas relief could have been granted on any recognized theory
column6: with the consequence that Hecks favorable termination requirement was inapplicable.

Does claim falls within a catchall category for someone who suffers an adverse effect from a failure not otherwise specified in the remedial section of the Act.  552a(g)(1)(D).  If a court determines in a subsection (g)(1)(D) suit that the agency acted in an intentional or willful manner

certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the eighth circuit
No. 026320. Argued December 10

Police officers went to petitioners home and advised him that they had come to discuss his involvement in drug distribution.  They told him that they had a federal warrant for his arrest and that a grand jury had indicted him for conspiracy to distribute methamphetamine.  During the course of a brief discussion
column2: petitioner made several inculpatory statements.  Once at the county jail
column3: petitioner was advised of his rights under Miranda v. Arizona
column5: and Patterson v. Illinois
column7: signed a waiver of those rights
column8: and reiterated his earlier statements.  Before trial
column9: he moved to suppress the inculpatory statements he made at his home and at the jail.  A Magistrate Judge recommended that the home statements be suppressed because the officers had not informed petitioner of his Miranda rights
column10: and that portions of his jailhouse statements be suppressed as fruits of the prior failure to provide Miranda warnings.  The District Court suppressed the unwarned home statements but admitted the jailhouse statements pursuant to Oregon v. Elstad
column12: concluding that petitioner had knowingly and voluntarily waived his Miranda rights before making the statements.  The Eighth Circuit affirmed the conviction
column13: holding that petitioners jailhouse statements were properly admitted under Elstad
column14: and that the officers had not violated his Sixth Amendment right to counsel under Patterson because they did not interrogate him at his home.

column1: Held:The Eighth Circuit erred in holding that the absence of an interrogation foreclosed petitioners claim that his jailhouse statements should have been suppressed as fruits of the statements taken from him at his home.  Pp.46.
(a)An accused is denied the protections of the Sixth Amendment when there [is] used against him at his trial  his own incriminating words
column2: which federal agents  deliberately elicited from him after he had been indicted and in the absence of his counsel.  Massiah v. United States
column4: 206.  This Court has consistently applied the deliberate-elicitation standard in subsequent Sixth Amendment cases
column5: see
column6: e.g.
column7: United States v. Henry
column9: and has expressly distinguished it from the Fifth Amendment custodial-interrogation standard
column10: see
column12: Michigan v. Jackson
column13: 475 U. S. 625.  There is no question here that the officers deliberately elicited information from petitioner at his home.  Because their discussion took place after petitioner had been indicted
column15: and in the absence of any waiver of his Sixth Amendment rights
column16: the officers actions violated the Sixth Amendment standards established in Massiah

column1: (b)Because of its erroneous determination that petitioner was not questioned in violation of Sixth Amendment standards
column2: the Eighth Circuit improperly conducted its fruits analysis under the Fifth Amendment.  In applying Elstad
column3: supra
column4: to hold that the admissibility of the jailhouse statements turned solely on whether they were knowing and voluntary
column5: the court did not reach the question whether the Sixth Amendment requires suppression of those statements on the ground that they were the fruits of previous questioning that violated the Sixth Amendment deliberate-elicitation standard.  As this Court has not had occasion to decide whether the rationale of Elstad applies when a suspect makes incriminating statements after a knowing and voluntary waiver of his right to counsel notwithstanding earlier police questioning in violation of Sixth Amendment standards
column6: the case is remanded to the Eighth Circuit to address this issue in the first instance.  Pp.56.

column1: |540 u.s. 419|"ILLINOIS v. LIDSTER
certiorari to the supreme court of illinois
No. 021060. Argued November 5

Police set up a highway checkpoint to obtain information from motorists about a hit-and-run accident occurring about one week earlier at the same location and time of night.  Officers stopped each vehicle for 10 to 15 seconds
column2: asked the occupants whether they had seen anything happen there the previous weekend
column3: and handed each driver a flyer describing and requesting information about the accident.  As respondent Lidster approached
column5: nearly hitting an officer.  The officer smelled alcohol on Lidsters breath.  Another officer administered a sobriety test and then arrested Lidster.  He was convicted in Illinois state court of driving under the influence of alcohol.  He challenged his arrest and conviction on the ground that the government obtained evidence through use of a checkpoint stop that violated the Fourth Amendment.  The trial court rejected that challenge
column6: but the state appellate court reversed.  The State Supreme Court agreed
column7: holding that
column8: in light of Indianapolis v. Edmond
column10: the stop was unconstitutional.

column1: Held:The checkpoint stop did not violate the Fourth Amendment.  Pp.28.
(a)Edmond does not govern the outcome of this case.  In Edmond
column3: absent special circumstances
column4: the Fourth Amendment forbids police to make stops without individualized suspicion at a checkpoint set up primarily for general crime control purposes.  531 U. S.
column5: at 41
column6: 44.  Specifically
column7: the checkpoint in Edmond was designed to ferret out drug crimes committed by the motorists themselves.  Here
column8: the stops primary law enforcement purpose was not to determine whether a vehicles occupants were committing a crime
column9: but to ask the occupants
column10: as members of the public
column11: for help in providing information about a crime in all likelihood committed by others.  Edmonds language
column12: as well as its context
column13: makes clear that an information-seeking stops constitutionality was not then before this Court.  Pp. 24.

column13: the context here (seeking information from the public) is one in which
column15: the concept of individualized suspicion has little role to play
column16: and an information-seeking stop is not the kind of event that involves suspicion
column18: of the relevant individual.  In addition
column19: information-seeking highway stops are less likely to provoke anxiety or to prove intrusive

That the importance of soliciting the publics assistance is offset to some degree by the need to stop a motorist

column5: at 40is not important enough to justify an Edmond-type rule here.  Finally

column7: and the Fourth Amendments normal insistence that the stop be reasonable in context will still provide an important legal limitation on checkpoint use.  Pp.46.

column1: (c)The checkpoint stop was constitutional.  In judging its reasonableness
column3: its constitutionality
column4: this Court looks to the gravity of the public concerns served by the seizure
